text: Kensington Oval during the Final of the 2007 Cricket World Cup, looking towards the Worrell, Weekes and Walcott stand. Kensington Oval is a sports stadium in Bridgetown, Barbados. The ground is used mainly for cricket and has been the venue for international matches featuring the West Indies cricket team. It was established as the home ground of Pickwick Cricket Club in 1882 and hosted the West Indies first home Test match in 1930. International sides played at the ground as early as 1895, and the ground was the first at which a combined West Indies side played first-class cricket.Kensington Oval, CricInfo. Retrieved 2010-04-01. One Day Internationals (ODI) have been played on the ground since 1985 and Twenty20 Internationals since 2008. The ground was rebuilt ahead of the 2007 Cricket World Cup and hosted the tournament final as well as the final of the 2010 ICC World Twenty20.Kensington Oval prepares for complete rebuild, CricInfo, 2004-09-03. Retrieved 2010-04-01.Kensington Oval, Brdigetown, West Indies Cricket Board. Retrieved 2020-01-14. Women's ODI and T20I matches have been held at the ground since 2010 and it hosted the final of the 2010 ICC Women's World Twenty20 competition.Kensington Oval, Bridgetown, CricketArchive. Retrieved 2020-01-14.English P (2010) Australia shut down NZ for thrilling trophy win, 16 May 2010. Retrieved 2020-01-14. In cricket, a five-wicket haul (also known as a "five-for" or "fifer") refers to a bowler taking five or more wickets in a single innings. This is regarded as a notable achievement.Pervez MA (2001) A Dictionary of Cricket, p.31. Hyderabad: Sangam Books (India). This article details the five-wicket hauls taken on the ground in official international Test, One Day International and Twenty20 International matches. The first five-wicket hauls in international matches on the ground were taken by England's Greville Stevens who took five wickets in each innings of the ground's first Test match in 1930.1st Test, England tour of West Indies at Bridgetown, Jan 11-16 1930, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-01-18. The first West Indian to do so was fast bowler Manny Martindale who took five wickets for 22 runs (5/22) against England in 1935.1st Test, England tour of West Indies at Bridgetown, Jan 8-10 1935, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-01-18. South African Charl Langeveldt took the first five-wicket haul in a One Day International on the ground, taking 5/62 against West Indies in 2005, a haul which included a hat- trick.3rd ODI, South Africa tour of West Indies at Bridgetown, May 11 2005, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-01-18. West Indian Anisa Mohammed took the first five-wicket haul by a woman on the ground in an ODI in 2012 and the following year took the grounds first T20I five-wicket haul.1st ODI, Sri Lanka Women tour of West Indies at Bridgetown, Apr 25 2012, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-01-08.1st Match (N), West Indies Tri-Nation Twenty20 Women's Series at Bridgetown, Oct 14 2013, CricInfo. Retrieved 2020-01-08. ==Key== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Symbol !
